paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Does TRAPPIST-1 b retain an atmosphere (versus being a bare rock), as inferred from JWST MIRI thermal phase-curve spectroscopy including structure near the 15 um CO2 band?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Observed TRAPPIST-1 b phase curve
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: 1 planet; JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Phase-resolved thermal spectra and phase-dependent brightness of TRAPPIST-1 b used to constrain day-night heat transport and spectral features.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Null scenario: no atmosphere
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Model comparison against the observed phase-curve and spectral structure
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Bare-rock, no-atmosphere model intended to represent minimal heat redistribution and a flat/featureless spectrum baseline.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: Retrieval family evaluated against the same phase-curve + spectrum
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere-bearing retrieval family with significant greenhouse gas absorption, targeting a detectable feature near the 15 um CO2 band.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere scenario with oxidized composition in which CO2 constraints are weaker, explored as a viable alternative given current data.

major_limitations: Single-planet target; results do not establish prevalence across M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions about circulation, opacity priors, and clouds affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
Degeneracies between composition, clouds/hazes, and circulation assumptions remain significant.
